    Morning | Face The
    Nation 















Hi everyone,
 
This morning, the Rutgers
  women’s basketball team spoke up about controversial comments made
  about them by radio host Don Imus. Their coach slammed what she called
  “racist and sexist remarks that are deplorable, despicable and
  unconscionable.”  The team captain said Imus had stolen “a moment
  of pure grace” from the athletes. Nancy Cordes will have the story and
  Richard Schlesinger will put the Imus controversy in perspective with a
  report on racism in America.
 
On Capitol Hill, momentum is building up to a likely
  clash over stem-cell research. As dual bills that would provide public
  funding for research using human embryos move through Congress, the White
  House says that President Bush’s veto pen is ready for whatever form of
  the legislation hits his desk. Sharyl Attkisson will have that story.
 
And Dr. Jon LaPook will look at one of the potential
  uses for stem cells: to help cure type 1 diabetes. The Journal of the
  American Medical Association reported that stem cells taken from the blood of
  a small sample of diabetes patients have helped the patients’ immune
  systems go months, and even years, without insulin. Fourteen out of the 15
  patients studied saw marked improvement in their diabetes, showing a glimmer
  of hope for a cure.
 
In other health news, researchers reported last
  night that the fastest-growing group of obese people in the United States are
  those 100 pounds or more overweight. These people are known as
  “severely obese.” The proportion of Americans fitting that
  description grew by an astonishing 50 percent between 2000 and 2005.  
 
For two years Army Specialist Mario Lozano has
  agonized about taking the life of an Italian secret agent while manning a
  roadblock on Iraq’s
  most dangerous highway.  Now, as he awaits trial in Italy for the death of Nicola
  Calipari, Lozano shares details of the shooting with our chief foreign
  correspondent Lara Logan. 
 
I hope you’ll join us.
 




Katie Couric
